Introduction

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) comprises a group of hematologic malignancies involving precursor cells committed to the myeloid lineage.

Pathogenesis and risk factors



Normal hematopoiesis is an active process in which cell proliferation and differentiation is highly regulated.  AML occurs when a single hematopoietic cell committed to the myeloid lineage loses this regulation.  As a result, there is uncontrolled clonal proliferation of early myeloid precursor cells (eg, myeloblasts) that lack the ability to differentiate into mature elements (eg, granulocytes, erythrocytes, platelets).  The malignant cells accumulate in the following sites:



  • Bone marrow:  Myeloid blasts interfere with normal hematopoiesis, and as a result, patients develop signs and symptoms of cytopenias (eg, fatigue and pallor from anemia, bruising from thrombocytopenia).
  • Peripheral blood:  As the myeloid blasts proliferate, they can exit the bone marrow and accumulate in the peripheral blood, resulting in leukocytosis.
  • Peripheral tissues:  Myeloid blasts can also infiltrate other tissues, leading to extramedullary manifestations (eg, gingival hypertrophy, nodular skin lesions).


AML is categorized into multiple subtypes based on specific molecular or morphologic features.  Acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) is a unique subtype of AML that occurs due to disrupted retinoic acid receptor alpha (RARα) function.  Normally, retinoic acid, a vitamin A derivative, binds to RARα on myeloid precursors to activate their differentiation.  In APL, a t(15;17) chromosomal translocation results in production of an abnormal fusion protein, PML-RARα, which has a much lower affinity for retinoic acid.  Therefore, physiologic levels of retinoic acid are insufficient to bind PML-RARα to induce differentiation.  As a result, myeloid precursor cells cannot differentiate beyond the promyelocyte stage (

figure 1
), accumulating in the bone marrow and peripheral blood.



AML develops following genetic mutations (altered DNA sequence) and epigenetic changes (modifications that alter gene expression without changing the DNA sequence) within myeloid precursor cells.  Factors that increase the risk for developing AML include:



  • DNA damage:  This occurs following exposure to ionizing radiation (
    figure 2
    ), industrial chemicals (eg, benzene), cytotoxic chemotherapy (eg, alkylating agents, topoisomerase inhibitors), retroviruses, and tobacco products.
  • Age:  Although AML can occur in children, its incidence increases with age (median age is 65 at symptom onset), likely due to accumulation of DNA damage over time.
  • Underlying genetic disorders:  In particular, conditions include those that are associated with loss of tumor suppressor genes (eg, loss of p53 in Li-Fraumeni syndrome) or impaired DNA repair (eg, impaired interstrand cross-link repair in Fanconi anemia).  In addition, patients with trisomy 21 are at increased risk for AML, likely related to increased expression of genes located on chromosome 21 that promote cells in the megakaryocyte-erythrocytic lineages during fetal hematopoiesis.
  • Myeloproliferative neoplasms (eg, chronic myeloid leukemia [CML]) or myelodysplastic syndrome.

Clinical presentation



Patients with AML typically have signs and symptoms of pancytopenia due to disrupted hematopoiesis:



  • Anemia causes fatigue, pallor, and decreased exercise tolerance.
  • Neutropenia can present with fever and opportunistic infections (eg, candidiasis, aspergillosis).
  • Thrombocytopenia causes easy bruising or bleeding (eg, gingival bleeding, petechiae).  In APL, bleeding can be severe and life-threatening due to concurrent coagulopathy (increased tissue factor expression and thrombin generation), causing disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) (
    figure 3
    ).


Patients with AML can develop other symptoms associated with local accumulation of myeloid blasts in others systems, including:



  • Skeletal:  progressive bone pain due to marrow cavity expansion
  • Ocular:  focal retinal ischemia (cotton-wool spots) and hemorrhage due to retinal arteriole occlusion
  • CNS:  headache, cranial nerve palsies, and weakness/paresthesia of the extremities due to spinal cord involvement
  • Integumentary:  nodular lesions (leukemia cutis)
  • Gastrointestinal:  gingival hypertrophy, hepatosplenomegaly
  • Circulatory:  myeloid blasts (less flexible than mature leukocytes).  At high concentrations (eg, >100,000/micoL, known as hyperleukocytosis), myeloid blasts increase blood viscosity and impede blood flow through capillaries in the brain (causing hemorrhage) and lungs (causing dyspnea and hypoxia).


Lymphadenopathy is not typical in AML because the malignant cells are myeloid (not lymphoid).

Diagnosis



In cases of suspected AML, initial laboratory evaluation includes:



  • Complete blood count:  anemia and thrombocytopenia with leukocytosis or leukopenia.  There may be blast cells in the differential.
  • Lactate dehydrogenase:  elevated due to high cell turnover
  • Serum chemistries:  can be normal or consistent with tumor lysis syndrome (
    figure 4
    ), a complication of rapid cell turnover in which large amounts of phosphate, potassium, and uric acid are released into systemic circulation; electrolyte derangements can lead to acute kidney injury and dysrhythmias.
  • Coagulation profile:  can be normal or consistent with DIC (especially in APL)


Identification of myeloid blasts based on morphologic, immunophenotypic, and molecular features confirms the diagnosis as follows:



  • Peripheral blood smear and/or bone marrow evaluation:  shows myeloid blast cells (generally ≥20% required for diagnosis) (
    image 1
    ), which may appear as large nucleated cells with prominent nucleoli and scant cytoplasm.  Auer rods (needle-shaped purple-red inclusions formed from fused granules), if present, are specific for myeloid cells.  In AML, the bone marrow shows hypercellularity.
  • Flow cytometry with immunophenotyping identifies cell surface markers that are specific to myeloid blasts (eg, myeloperoxidase, CD33) (
    figure 5
    ).
  • Cytogenetic and molecular studies identify specific chromosomal abnormalities (eg, t[15;17], inv[16]) and mutations that are associated with AML.  Of note, the diagnosis is confirmed if one of these AML-defining genetic abnormalities are present, even if the blast percentage is <20%.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis for AML includes other hematologic malignancies and conditions that can present with similar symptoms:



  • Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL):  is a type of acute leukemia that involves lymphoid, rather than myeloid, cell lines.  Patients can have similar pancytopenia and bone pain; however, lymphadenopathy is more common in patients with ALL.  Lymphoid blasts express different cell surface markers (eg, CD19, CD20 for B-ALL; CD3, CD7 for T-ALL).
  • Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS):  comprises a group of clonal bone marrow disorders characterized by ineffective hematopoiesis and signs of various cytopenias.  However, the bone marrow and peripheral smears often show abnormally differentiated cells (eg, hypogranular neutrophils, erythroid precursors with misshapen nuclei) consistent with dysplastic changes, and the percentage of blasts is <20% (
    image 2
    ).
  • Chronic myeloid leukemia (CML):  can progress to blast crisis, the most aggressive phase of disease.  Blast crisis in CML can cause splenomegaly, fatigue, cytopenia, and a high percentage of blasts in the bone marrow and peripheral blood.  However, the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome (abnormal chromosome 22 containing a BCR::ABL1 fusion) in mature myeloid cells can distinguish CML from de novo AML.
  • Aplastic anemia:  is characterized by pancytopenia and hypocellular bone marrow.  Bone marrow biopsy reveals markedly decreased hematopoietic cells and increased fat cells.
  • Infectious mononucleosis:  caused by Epstein-Barr virus or cytomegalovirus can result in pancytopenia, fever, fatigue, and hepatosplenomegaly.  Peripheral smear reveals circulating atypical lymphocytes (
    image 3
    ), not myeloid blast cells.

Management



The mainstay of AML management is with chemotherapy.  Induction therapy is initiated, which typically involves a combination of cytarabine and an anthracycline (eg, daunorubicin), to induce remission (no detectable myeloid blast cells in the bone marrow and peripheral blood).  After induction therapy, patients with high-risk features (eg, monosomy 7) typically undergo allogeneic stem cell transplantation.



Patients with AML are at high risk for complications related to the disease itself as well as chemotherapy.  Supportive care in these patients may require transfusion (due to prolonged or worsening pancytopenia), nutritional support, and infection prevention (eg, antimicrobial prophylaxis).



The management of APL is different due to the unique properties of PML-RARα.  The fusion protein's low affinity for physiologic levels of retinoic acid can be overcome by providing pharmacologic doses of retinoic acid (all-trans retinoic acid [ATRA]).  As a result, the malignant promyelocytes can overcome the blockade and differentiate into normal neutrophils.  ATRA is often given in combination with arsenic trioxide, which induces apoptosis and proteolysis of PML-RARα.  ATRA-based therapy induces remission in approximately 90% of patients, but these patients should be closely monitored for differentiation syndrome (release of cytokines from maturing myeloid cells, manifesting with fever, peripheral edema, and respiratory distress).

Complications



Patients with AML are at risk for complications, including:



  • Leukostasis:  Patients who have high white blood cell counts are at increased risk for leukostasis, a medical emergency in which myeloid blasts increase blood viscosity and impede blood flow through small capillaries in the brain (causing hemorrhage) and lungs (causing dyspnea with hypoxia).
  • Tumor lysis syndrome:  This complication is the consequence of rapid cell lysis that may occur at diagnosis or during induction therapy.  Management involves aggressive intravenous hydration and correction of hyperuricemia and electrolyte abnormalities while closely monitoring cardiac and renal status.
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation:  This syndrome is most associated with the APL subtype.  Supportive blood products (eg, fresh frozen plasma) should be administered as needed while treating the underlying malignancy.

Prognosis



The prognosis of AML varies, depending on both host factors, disease characteristics, and response to initial treatment.



The 5-year overall survival rate is 20%-30% but varies depending on age.  Younger patients generally have a better prognosis, with a 5-year overall survival rate of 65%-70% in children.  Those with multiple comorbidities have a worse prognosis.  Certain genetic abnormalities are associated with better (eg, inv[16]) or worse (eg, monosomy 7) outcomes.



The prognosis for APL is more favorable than other subtypes, and many patients can be cured with treatment.  However, patients are often initially at increased risk for life-threatening hemorrhage due to associated coagulopathies.  Therefore, those with suspected APL should receive ATRA and supportive blood products as soon as possible to reduce the risk for mortality.



Patients who achieve remission are at risk for long-term morbidities (eg, cardiotoxicity from anthracyclines, secondary malignancies) related to chemotherapy and should be routinely monitored.

Summary



Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) comprises a group of hematologic malignancies involving myeloid precursor cells.  AML is the most common type of acute leukemia in adults.  Patients generally have signs of bone marrow failure (eg, fatigue due to anemia, easy bleeding due to thrombocytopenia).  Treatment involves chemotherapy with the potential use of targeted treatments.  Prognosis is dependent on various factors, including age and disease characteristics.
